bibl.title: Letter from H.H. Donnally to Howard A. Kelly, October 17, 1907

div1.p: Donnally thanks Kelly for his fairness to Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from H.H. Donnally to Howard A. Kelly, October 17, 1907
div1.opener:
HOURS:
UNTIL 9:30 A.M.
1:00 P.M.
4:20 TO 6:00 P.M.
HOURS ALSO AT 814 17Th ST.,
IN ASSOCIATION WITH DR. H. C. YARROW
V
DR. H. H. DONNALLY
OFFICE AND RESIDENCE, 1016 14TH STREET. N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
October 17, 1907.
Dr. H. A. Kelly,
#1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Dr. Kelly,
div1.p:
I am sorry that I had to leave before the meeting
of the Historical Society adjourned last Monday, and thus was
unable to bid you good-bye and to tell you how much I enjoyed
your hospitality. The whole evening was a most enjoyable one
and all of the Washington party were pleased and outspoken in
their praise.

As I listened to your very interesting paper I was impressed
to James Carroll
with your fairness/and the full share of credit which you pointed
out as his due. I feel sure that had the poor fellow been there,
tears of gratitude would have appeared in his eyes as he listened
to you, and afterwards he would have expressed to you his grateful
approval and thanks.

Dr. Munroe understood that he was to be called on, and had
prepared remarks which I enclose you, herewith.

Upon receipt of a letter from Dr. Sladen requesting it I am
sending him a copy of my remarks.
